text:
I don't follow the problem.

Reading the bug report you reference doesn't make it very clear to
me either (the comments seem to be talking at cross purposes,
so I can't tell who's fix went in).

Can you attach a sample SVG that shows the issue, with a
discussion of what you expect the rendering to be?

The problem... the problem is that when I take any svg with graphics out 
of inkscape, and try to use it with any other svg program, the graphics
are way bigger than they should be. My theory as to why that is, 
was that every other svg program seems to implement the unit spec incorrectly.
Particularly, the spec says that numbers without units on them should
be interpreted in user units, which are equivalent to 1 px, not 1pt,
which is what everyone seems to be implementing. I don't know anything
about graphics units, but looking online says that 1pt = 1.25 px.

Sample svg? Any svg with graphics (like a large square) 
produced by inkscape should suffice.

Can you reproduce, or should I retest? (I don't have batik w/ pdf
installed right now, but I can reinstall for testing). IIRC what I 
was trying to do is convert an inkscape svg to a pdf document using batik,
and it was resulting in something that was the wrong size, and cut off
at the end of the page.
creator: ivg2@cornell.edu
deweese@apache.org
text:
The problem is that Inscape is relying on undefined
behaviour.  It is assuming that the relationship
is 1.25px = 1pt.  It should really provide a
viewbox attribute that explictly provides the mapping
between the width/height real world units and the
userspace of the SVG element.

It might be a nice enhancement to the PDF transcoder
if it would respect the '-dpi' flag like the rest of
the transcoders, but it is not a violation of the SVG
specification.

I just got the lastest copy of the PDF transcoder from FOP.
It does handle this properly now.  I'll deliver to Batik
shortly (next day or two).
